msContents.summary: Side 1: Letter from Heraclides to Hatres, reproaching him for not sending 20 drachmae. (Grenfell & Hunt) Side 2: Parts of 19 lines from a taxing-account. (Grenfell & Hunt)

msItemStruct.note: Text is on both sides: Side 1 is the main text, a letter from Heraclides to Hatres, 24 lines written against the fibers. Side 2 contains parts of 19 lines, written with the fibers, of a tax account. Text (on Side 1) mentions the village of Paomis.
Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology collection

supportDesc.support: 10.0 x 21.5cm. The right, top and bottom margins are mostly intact. The left margin is badly damaged, especially in the central portion of the papyrus, with the loss of the beginnings of several lines. There is also a hole in the top-right corner.

provenance.p: Excavated by Grenfell and Hunt (1896-7) on behalf of the Egyptian Exploration Fund, and donated to the University Museum in return for its support (1904, Dr. Parrish Collection).

div.ab: Side 1: Heraclides to his dearest Hatres, greeting. You ought without my writing to you to have sent me by Saetas the 20 drachmae, for you know that I paid them here to my partners; but you have waited all this time without paying me. Be sure therefore to give this sum at once to the bearer of this letter, that you may save me too from trouble. Mind that you do not fail and thereby cause me to come to you and dispute with you about it; for indeed I found you at Paomis the other day and wanted to welcome you; but you would not stay, being oppressed by an evil conscience. (Grenfell & Hunt)
